commit_message:
Provide sensible default cell group names

By providing sensible default group names for cells, the user no longer
has to define the group names for each cell manually in group vars.

This also updates the CI test, which uses non-default group names.

Partially Implements: blueprint support-nova-cells
Change-Id: Iaca3462698e29d742876b677b05c3a5c115b8caf

commit_message:
Add 'clients' command for installing OSC clients

Support installing OSC clients compatible with the services that are
managed by the deployment. Clients can be installed in a virtualenv, but
are by default installed on the deploy node (where the admin-openrc.sh
file already is.)

Usage:

  kolla-ansible -i INVENTORY clients

Change-Id: I8d2f9b78668bac5e07269411914a18c298b88bc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/76/671576/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Install OpenStack clients on the deploy node hosts: localhost become: true tasks: - name: Generating requirements.txt template: src: "roles/common/templates/requirements.txt.j2" dest: "{{ node_config }}/requirements.txt" run_once: True - pip: requirements: "{{ node_config }}/requirements.txt" virtualenv: "{{ virtualenv is none | ternary(omit, virtualenv) }}" extra_args: "-c https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt?h=stable/{{ openstack_release }}" run_once: True

commit_message:
Add script to start apache2 easily

Sometimes it is handy to be able to just run apache
but this isn't possible without first sourcing the
httpd_setup.sh. Add a little helper script so
it can be used as the docker command.

Change-Id: I23ca2e402c491f20985b2416c173edd1564cc170
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/44/842244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Script to setup and start apache2 . /usr/local/bin/kolla_httpd_setup /usr/sbin/apache2 -DFOREGROUND

commit_message:
nova: Enable apic removal workaround for bug #1939108 when using QEMU

This change enables [workarounds]libvirt_disable_apic when devstack is
deployed using the libvirt virt driver and qemu virt type in an effort
to avoid issues outlined in bug #1939108 caused by the older kernel
currently used in Cirros 0.5.2.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/805631
Closes-Bug: #1939108
Change-Id: Ibb6c34133bb1c95ef11cc59d9b12a0f65502c61b
(cherry picked from commit 1e86a25cc28e34d7f73a4c6ccbbc3fc667598d50)
(cherry picked from commit e5255369207f78747b59fe187f910de9a8daff58)
(cherry picked from commit 3730e91e153bacd9021cddd04346d60944aedab2)
(cherry picked from commit d9c6a27149f0c0cd3a7ba93689e93f2979f6a5ed)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/36/805636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Workaround bug #1939108 if [[ "$VIRT_DRIVER" == "libvirt" && "$LIBVIRT_TYPE" == "qemu" ]]; then iniset $NOVA_CPU_CONF workarounds libvirt_disable_apic True fi

commit_message:
nova: Enable apic removal workaround for bug #1939108 when using QEMU

This change enables [workarounds]libvirt_disable_apic when devstack is
deployed using the libvirt virt driver and qemu virt type in an effort
to avoid issues outlined in bug #1939108 caused by the older kernel
currently used in Cirros 0.5.2.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/805630
Closes-Bug: #1939108
Change-Id: Ibb6c34133bb1c95ef11cc59d9b12a0f65502c61b
(cherry picked from commit 1e86a25cc28e34d7f73a4c6ccbbc3fc667598d50)
(cherry picked from commit e5255369207f78747b59fe187f910de9a8daff58)
(cherry picked from commit 3730e91e153bacd9021cddd04346d60944aedab2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/34/805634/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Workaround bug #1939108 if [[ "$VIRT_DRIVER" == "libvirt" && "$LIBVIRT_TYPE" == "qemu" ]]; then iniset $NOVA_CPU_CONF workarounds libvirt_disable_apic True fi

commit_message:
nova: Enable apic removal workaround for bug #1939108 when using QEMU

This change enables [workarounds]libvirt_disable_apic when devstack is
deployed using the libvirt virt driver and qemu virt type in an effort
to avoid issues outlined in bug #1939108 caused by the older kernel
currently used in Cirros 0.5.2.

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflict caused by Ie6eec4e140c7464936cf0b0c6307026a94c9f4ee
not being present in stable/victoria.

Conflicts:
    lib/nova

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/805629
Closes-Bug: #1939108
Change-Id: Ibb6c34133bb1c95ef11cc59d9b12a0f65502c61b
(cherry picked from commit 1e86a25cc28e34d7f73a4c6ccbbc3fc667598d50)
(cherry picked from commit e5255369207f78747b59fe187f910de9a8daff58)

commit_message:
Add the function of docker login before pushing

Because kolla lacks the function of docker login before pushing images to
the registry, so add the following code to implement this function.
First, add the related parameters in kolla/common/config.py, such as
registry_username, registry_password, and registry_email.
Second, add the function of docker login call before pushing images in kolla/
image/build.py.

Change-Id: I84c605581a436182f0456a7f5919142a731e9b78
Closes-Bug: #1642856

commit_message:
Make ironic cross gating voting

The majority of ironic's CI is built upon devstack, and thus some changes
which may pass setting up a stock devstack, may still ultimately cripple
Ironic's CI. Mainly in terms of integration with other projects.

As such, it seems logical to make the CI job voting such that breaking
changes have visibility upfront.

Also re-names the job name to the more modern name as the
driver name the job mentions was explicitly removed some time
ago in favor of what is called driver composition.

This change came out of a discussion of Neutron changing the default to
OVN. Which while problematic for Ironic due to a lack of necessary DHCP
server capabilities, the topic of the neturon-legacy/neutron plugin came
up and Ironic, and at the time of this change Ironic uses the "neutron"
plugin. As such, abrupt removal of the plugin would be a fairly
catastropic change for Ironic, hence the need for cross-gating.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741254/
Change-Id: I5d6a4fccf37521f0104091ecb8055a08f760fa05

commit_message:
fix the name of uwsgi from uwsgi to uWSGI.
it produces a error message that ls can not access uwsgi, No such file or directory when using comman ls uwsgi. Because package name starts with uWSGI not uwsgi.

Change-Id: Ia6d1617f0d3538d8728d4da689368cf7c96f02fc

Otherwise, we'll have it placed twice.

commit_message:
Make cirros image download automatically on multiarch

This makes devstack download the right cirros image automatically when
running on multiarch nodes such as aarch64, x86_64 and ppc64le.

Change-Id: I056a68b01f84b2cb40f8af8e0962640c86e139d6

floating IP range set up by neutron.

subject: Install swift and cinder client from pip if needed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-29 18:58:41.000000000', 'files': ['lib/cinder', 'lib/swift'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/059eef6dfa6023b5e1eac554a280c3d2533f6b57', 'message': "Install swift and cinder client from pip if needed

We have logic to install swiftclient if swift is enabled because
glance uses swift by default if it's enabled. However, if swiftclient
isn't in the list of libs to install from source, we no-op. This was
fine when we were accidentally getting python-swiftclient from
the test-requirements of glance-store, but it's an actual need, so
we need to also fall back to installing from pip. Same story
with cinderclient which is also pulled in originally from glance_store
test-requirements.

Change-Id: I658d190557a993f3cfe6ed55e5d2159f47f7d35e
"}]
commit_message:
Install swift and cinder client from pip if needed

We have logic to install swiftclient if swift is enabled because
glance uses swift by default if it's enabled. However, if swiftclient
isn't in the list of libs to install from source, we no-op. This was
fine when we were accidentally getting python-swiftclient from
the test-requirements of glance-store, but it's an actual need, so
we need to also fall back to installing from pip. Same story
with cinderclient which is also pulled in originally from glance_store
test-requirements.

Change-Id: I658d190557a993f3cfe6ed55e5d2159f47f7d35e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/22/715722/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: else pip_install_gr python-swiftclient

commit_message:
zuul: Added reference tenant configuration

For users who want to consume DevStack in their own Zuul tenants,
they can use this sample tenant configuration which includes how to
loads jobs and all projects.

Change-Id: Ie7ad88f296976e45c4b115a3de4e70aead071733
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/54/713454/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The DevStack repository includes a set of Zuul CI jobs which can be used by any project inside OpenStack but also by third parties that need to integrate their systems and test them against OpenStack using Zuul. The following is an example of a Zuul tenant with all the needed ``required-projects`` which consumes DevStack. .. code-block:: yaml - tenant: name: devstack max-nodes-per-job: 10 report-build-page: true source: gerrit: untrusted-projects: - zuul/zuul-jobs # Include all the necessary jobs - include: [job, nodeset] projects: - openstack/devstack - openstack/tempest # Include all the required-projects - include: [] projects: - openstack/cinder - openstack/glance - openstack/keystone - openstack/neutron - openstack/nova - openstack/oslo.cache - openstack/oslo.concurrency - openstack/oslo.config - openstack/oslo.context - openstack/oslo.db - openstack/oslo.i18n - openstack/oslo.log - openstack/oslo.messaging - openstack/oslo.middleware - openstack/oslo.policy - openstack/oslo.privsep - openstack/oslo.reports - openstack/oslo.rootwrap - openstack/oslo.serialization - openstack/oslo.service - openstack/oslo.utils - openstack/oslo.versionedobjects - openstack/oslo.vmware - openstack/placement - openstack/requirements - openstack/swift Jobs ----

subject: Fix error in configure_nova_hypervisor with hardware Ironic node
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-22 21:39:44.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova_plugins/hypervisor-ironic'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/7b7e1de49ac4e24f46808864293bda050812cd5a', 'message': 'Fix error in configure_nova_hypervisor with hardware Ironic node

Trying to deploy OpenStack environment consisting of ironic nova
hypervisor & hardware Ironic node (not VM Ironic node) with devstack
got failed.

Devstack error says error occurred while calling configure_libvirt
in configure_nova_hypervisor. This happens because libvirt related
packages are not installed when specifying "VIRT_DRIVER=ironic"
and "IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True".

To fix this problem, this commit add "if" statement to check
Ironic node is hardware or not using "is_ironic_hardware" function
in "function-common" file.

Change-Id: I1113478175fadec79d0f8bf6ae842ed86e5e686b
Closes-Bug: #1834985
(cherry picked from commit 705e9cb5dc8b63c902f588d29271686501be0c6e)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix error in configure_nova_hypervisor with hardware Ironic node

Trying to deploy OpenStack environment consisting of ironic nova
hypervisor & hardware Ironic node (not VM Ironic node) with devstack
got failed.

Devstack error says error occurred while calling configure_libvirt
in configure_nova_hypervisor. This happens because libvirt related
packages are not installed when specifying "VIRT_DRIVER=ironic"
and "IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True".

To fix this problem, this commit add "if" statement to check
Ironic node is hardware or not using "is_ironic_hardware" function
in "function-common" file.

Change-Id: I1113478175fadec79d0f8bf6ae842ed86e5e686b
Closes-Bug: #1834985
(cherry picked from commit 705e9cb5dc8b63c902f588d29271686501be0c6e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/75/703875/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! is_ironic_hardware; then configure_libvirt fi

subject: Customize the authentication error timeout page in modOIDC
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-09 16:17:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/a2ba2426b1a2bacbc697b64bc716547753640ddf', 'message': 'Customize the authentication error timeout page in modOIDC

There is a situation that happens when a user triggers an authentication
in OpenStack that uses Identity federation, which leads users to a blank
page with an error message that might not be that clear to users. If the
user takes too long to enter his/her credentials in the login page of
the IdP, the user sees a page saying that the authentication took too
much and that the user must try it again. However, if the user tries
again, he is already logged in to the IdP, and then the user gets access
direct to Horizon. This whole process can be a bit confusing for users,
and they saw an error page after the login, which leads them to think
that there was an error in the authentication, but then when he/she
tries again, everything just works.

Therefore, to handle such cases we propose Kolla-ansble to use a custom
error page that has an automatic redirect if the error happens.

Change-Id: Iebda3ca7a5f9cef7e5e0930fc4f70764774d6ed5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-03-09 16:19:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/6f370879837356fd205cd07cac4f6e76c9641d89', 'message': 'Customize the authentication error timeout page in modOIDC

There is a situation that happens when a user triggers an authentication
in OpenStack that uses Identity federation, which leads users to a blank
page with an error message that might not be that clear to users. If the
user takes too long to enter his/her credentials in the login page of
the IdP, the user sees a page saying that the authentication took too
much and that the user must try it again. However, if the user tries
again, he is already logged in to the IdP, and then the user gets access
direct to Horizon. This whole process can be a bit confusing for users,
and they saw an error page after the login, which leads them to think
that there was an error in the authentication, but then when he/she
tries again, everything just works.

Therefore, to handle such cases we propose Kolla-ansble to use a custom
error page that has an automatic redirect if the error happens.

The timeout is managed by "OIDCStateTimeout" variable. The default
(which is what we have in place now) is 300 seconds (5 minutes):
https://github.com/zmartzone/mod_auth_openidc/blob/d13ee0e4bd2cef94c4d2b55829310175288e0bdf/src/mod_auth_openidc.c#L651).

I would not recommend the increase of this timeout though. I would rather
decrease this value; 5 minutes to such an operation is already too much.
This variable can be overridden via wsgi-keystone.conf file.

To customize the error page we have the following variable
"OIDCHTMLErrorTemplate". The template is processed in the following
line: https://github.com/zmartzone/mod_auth_openidc/blob/f2b8315cd48faba04320e9a06fc52b57f0989dcb/src/util.c#L1619.
As we can see, there is no default page. The default HTML is hardcoded
in C++, and the template requires two "%s" placeholders that will
receive the title of the error message and the full description of the error.

Change-Id: Iebda3ca7a5f9cef7e5e0930fc4f70764774d6ed5

Change-Id: Iebda3ca7a5f9cef7e5e0930fc4f70764774d6ed5
'}]
commit_message:
Customize the authentication error timeout page in modOIDC

There is a situation that happens when a user triggers an authentication
in OpenStack that uses Identity federation, which leads users to a blank
page with an error message that might not be that clear to users. If the
user takes too long to enter his/her credentials in the login page of
the IdP, the user sees a page saying that the authentication took too
much and that the user must try it again. However, if the user tries
again, she/he is already logged in to the IdP, and then the user gets
access direct to Horizon. This whole process can be a bit confusing for
users, and they saw an error page after the login, which leads them to
think that there was an error in the authentication, but then when
he/she tries again, everything just works.

Therefore, to handle such cases we propose Kolla-ansble to use a custom
error page that has an automatic redirect if the error happens.

The timeout is managed by "OIDCStateTimeout" variable. The default
(which is what we have in place now) is 300 seconds (5 minutes):
https://github.com/zmartzone/mod_auth_openidc/blob/d13ee0e4bd2cef94c4d2b55829310175288e0bdf/src/mod_auth_openidc.c#L651).

I would not recommend the increase of this timeout though. I would
rather decrease this value; 5 minutes to such an operation is already
too much. This variable can be overridden via wsgi-keystone.conf file.

To customize the error page we have the following variable
"OIDCHTMLErrorTemplate". The template is processed in the following
line: https://github.com/zmartzone/mod_auth_openidc/blob/f2b8315cd48faba04320e9a06fc52b57f0989dcb/src/util.c#L1619.
As we can see, there is no default page. The default HTML is hardcoded
in C++, and the template requires two "%s" placeholders that will
receive the title of the error message and the full description of the error.

Change-Id: Iebda3ca7a5f9cef7e5e0930fc4f70764774d6ed5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/06/832806/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: modoidc_error_page_retry_login_delay_milliseconds: 5000

commit_message:
Fix api layer become slow when shutdown one control node

* add memcache_socket_timeout configuration variables
  and set the default value 0.25[0]
* add memcache_dead_retry configuration variables
  and set the default value to 900s[1]

* [0] https://review.opendev.org/519353
* [1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.cache/latest/configuration/#cache.memcache_dead_retry
Closes-Bug: #1980739

Change-Id: I47db333a1f0d735703e6559e2130315189e3d56e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/87/849487/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: memcache_dead_retry = 3600 memcache_socket_timeout = 0.25

commit_message:
Support exposing prometheus_server externally

This avoids the need to use a proxy, or some other means, to connect to
Prometheus. This is disabled by default and can be enabled by setting
enable_prometheus_server_external to true.

Change-Id: Ia0af044ff436c2a204b357750a16ff49fcdfec45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/95/828695/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: prometheus_server_external: enabled: "{{ enable_prometheus_server | bool }}" mode: "http" external: true port: "{{ prometheus_port }}" auth_user: "{{ prometheus_user }}" auth_pass: "{{ prometheus_password }}"

commit_message:
libvirt: add optional cpu-model configuration

Some deployment may have the desir for guests running on host to
expose a certain set of capabilities.

This change gives to operator ability to set a model for guests
deployed. It's especially useful for deployment running different host
CPUs model.

Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@industrialdiscipline.com>
Change-Id: I74da907182490311e8a79197ce73fddbfe4f7799
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/17/856517/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Some deployment may have the desir for guests running on host to expose a certain set of capabilities. This updates gives to operator ability to set a model for guests deployed. It's especially useful for deployment running different host CPUs models.

commit_message:
Add all ports during ironic introspection.

We would better collect all ports during introspection for providing
more than one tenant network/port during provision.

Change-Id: I56bb569d9db300dc3f04afb5187a9fc7e9d6338a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/30/857030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: add_ports = all

commit_message:
Remove "distutils" library

Library "distutils" is deprecated in Python 3.10:
https://peps.python.org/pep-0632/

This patch does the following replacements, that provide the same
functionality and API:
- distutils.version.StrictVersion -> packaging.version.Version

Change-Id: Ie315004715a1cb5a91dd54bc64b0a8fd0af650ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/03/857003/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from packaging.version import Version if Version(ansible_version) < Version('2.11.0'): docker_version = Version(client.api_version) return docker_version >= Version('1.25')
deleted_lines: from distutils.version import StrictVersion if StrictVersion(ansible_version) < StrictVersion('2.11.0'): docker_version = StrictVersion(client.api_version) return docker_version >= StrictVersion('1.25')

commit_message:
Allows for multiple Ceph Conf files

Makes it possible for a user to store multiple ceph.conf files in
the `{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph/` directory and for these
files to be copied into the cinder_volume and cinder_backup containers
in the appropriate location.

This proposal also considers the legacy
`{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph.conf` file so that already existing
deployments will not be affected.

Implements: blueprint multiple-ceph-conf-file
Signed-off-by: Juan Pablo Suazo <jsuazo@whitestack.com>
Change-Id: I14b4da178463abacde7039a893d8f8af3f23faad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/29/848029/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name : Find ceph conf files find: paths: "{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/" patterns: '(^ceph\d*\.conf$)' use_regex: yes delegate_to: localhost register: ceph_conf_files - "{{item.0.path}}" - "{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/{{ item.1.key }}/ceph.conf" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ item.1.key }}/{{item.0.path.split('/')[-1] }}" - item.1.value.enabled | bool - inventory_hostname in groups[item.1.value.group] - item.1.key in services_need_config with_nested: - "{{ ceph_conf_files.files }}" - "{{ cinder_services | dict2items }}" notify: - Restart {{ item.1.key }} container
deleted_lines: - "{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/ceph.conf" - "{{ node_custom_config }}/cinder/{{ item.key }}/ceph.conf" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ item.key }}/ceph.conf" - item.value.enabled | bool - inventory_hostname in groups[item.value.group] - item.key in services_need_config with_dict: "{{ cinder_services }}" notify: - Restart {{ item.key }} container

subject: Support creating roles and assigning to service users

commit_message:
Support creating roles and assigning to service users

This allows creation of custom roles and assigning roles to service
users. This can be useful when policy has been customised.

Change-Id: If6678883b6cb65e628a4cca948a93674d251446c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/52/774452/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_ks_register_user_roles: "{{ nova_ks_user_roles }}"

commit_message:
[docs] Add more advanced service configuration examples

Add examples of OpenStack projects (e.g. nova) and services (e.g. nova
scheduler). Add examples on how to override configuration files for
OpenStack projects, project service and  project-service on specified host

Closes-Bug: #1916680
Change-Id: I11a7547a906f761b7aba5a34dc65f7cd716bd770
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/94/817994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The directory to merge custom config files the Kolla's config filesgenerally look for a file based on the OpenStack project (e.g. ``nova``) and service (e.g. ``nova-scheduler``) in the following locations: * ``/etc/kolla/config/<< config file >>`` * ``/etc/kolla/config/<< OpenStack project name >>/<< config file >>`` * ``/etc/kolla/config/<< OpenStack project name >>/<< hostname >>/<< config file >>`` But these locations sometimes vary and you should check the config task in the appropriate Ansible role for a full list of supported locations. If you want to override an OpenStack project (e.g. ``nova``) configuration file, the following location is available: If you want to override the OpenStack project configuration file (e.g ``nova.conf``), the following locations are supported, assuming that you have Nova services running on hosts called ``controller-0001``, ``controller-0002`` and ``controller-0003``: If you want to override a specific service (e.g. ``nova-scheduler``) configuration file, then the override file should be added in a new directory, named based on the OpenStack project (in this case ``nova``): If you want to override the service's configuration file (e.g ``nova-scheduler.conf``), the following locations are supported, assuming that you have Nova services running on hosts called ``controller-0001``, ``controller-0002`` and ``controller-0003``: * ``/etc/kolla/config/nova/controller-0001/nova-scheduler.conf`` * ``/etc/kolla/config/nova/controller-0002/nova-scheduler.conf`` * ``/etc/kolla/config/nova/controller-0003/nova-scheduler.conf`` Using this mechanism, overrides can be configured per-project, per project on specific host,
deleted_lines: # The directory to merge custom config files the kolla's config filesgenerally look for a file in ``/etc/kolla/config/<< config file >>``, ``/etc/kolla/config/<< service name >>/<< config file >>`` or ``/etc/kolla/config/<< service name >>/<< hostname >>/<< config file >>``, but these locations sometimes vary and you should check the config task in the appropriate Ansible role for a full list of supported locations. For example, in the case of ``nova.conf`` the following locations are supported, assuming that you have services using ``nova.conf`` running on hosts called ``controller-0001``, ``controller-0002`` and ``controller-0003``:Using this mechanism, overrides can be configured per-project,

commit_message:
Make iPXE NBP filename configurable

Partial-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1959203
Change-Id: I825766eb157d37b982b2615c90976c0ed95617c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/30/826630/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The configuation option: ``ironic_dnsmasq_boot_file`` can be used to modify the filename of the network boot program used to chainload iPXE: .. code-block:: yaml ironic_dnsmasq_ipxe_boot_file: ipxe-snponly-x86_64.efi This only takes effect when you have set ``enable_ironic_ipxe`` to a truthy value.

commit_message:
Add support for dedicated RabbitMQ clusters for cell controllers

Support deploying a corresponding RabbitMQ for each cells controller,
The cells are defined in the inventory, and each cells setting is
provided by group_vars.
Support nova multi-cells, multi-RabbitQM deployment topology.

Implements: blueprint cellsv2-rabbitmq-support
Change-Id: If86f48d6de1aa1f18c44eda115b58890c4a12c4e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/84/823084/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ################### # Cells ################### nova_cell_name: '' nova_cell_rpc_group_name: 'nova-conductor' nova_cell_rpc_user: "{{ om_rpc_user }}"

commit_message:
Add support to Dynamic ceilometer compute pollsters

With patches [1] and [2], we are now able to create Ceilometer compute
dynamic pollsters. Therefore, this means that we can create custom host
command pollsters to be executed in Ceilometer compute nodes. However,
Kolla-ansible is not copying the "pollster.d" folder in Ceilometer
compute docker instances. Therefore, this patch adds that process, and
thus enables one to manage Ceilometer compute dynamic pollsters via Kolla-ansible.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/852021
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/855953

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/852021

Depends-on:  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/855953
Change-Id: Idb6632d6c9a94f33c7baad81dc4e821ea781b480
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/01/857501/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: }{% endif %}{% if should_copy_dynamic_pollster_definitions %}, { "source": "{{ container_config_directory }}/{{ ceilometer_dynamic_pollsters_local_folder }}", "dest": "/etc/ceilometer/pollsters.d", "owner": "ceilometer", "perm": "0700"

subject: Adds api_hostnames to baremetal role
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-08-03 14:50:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collection-kolla/commit/4c52d003ede6cc5c115e61e7ba92dab148ebba2b', 'message': 'Adds api_hostnames to baremetal role

This allows you to customise the entries that are added to /etc/hosts.
The names in here determine the name used to register the compute service,
since nova uses socket.gethostname(). The fact `nodename` seems
to be looked up as follows:

- ansible calls platform.node() from standard library
- platform.node seems to use os.uname() from standard library
- os.uname seems to do a uname syscall
- uname syscall uses data in /proc/sys/kernel/hostname

Generally this should be set to shortname[1]. The nodename fact will
therefore in general return the shortname. Instead, we should explictly
set the FQDN so that we can reliably control what socket.gethostname()
returns.

[1] https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/239950

Change-Id: I1ffc7ac4cbd35bbf1d432b76ccd18298dcd57315

This allows you to customise the entries that are added to /etc/hosts.
The names in here determine the name used to register the compute service,
since nova uses socket.getfqdn()[1]. The fact `nodename` seems
to be looked up as follows:

- ansible calls platform.node() from standard library
- platform.node seems to use os.uname() from standard library

set the FQDN so that we can reliably control what socket.getfqdn()

commit_message:
Adds api_hostnames to baremetal role

This allows you to customise the entries that are added to /etc/hosts.
One reason you might want to do this is to get `hostname -f` to return
the correct FQDN. The data strucutre in the kernel is limited
to 64 chars so it is not always possible to set the hostname to the FQDN[1].
The recommended solution is add the FQDN to /etc/hosts[2].

[1] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/hostnamectl.html#hostname%20%5BNAME%5D
[2] https://manpages.debian.org/bullseye/hostname/hostname.1.en.html#THE_FQDN

Change-Id: I1ffc7ac4cbd35bbf1d432b76ccd18298dcd57315
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collection-kolla refs/changes/31/852031/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | A new variable, ``api_hostnames``, can be used to customise the list of hostnames associated with the api address in /etc/hosts. This only takes effect when ``customize_etc_hosts`` is set to ``True``.

subject: Always run the rabbitmq heartbeat inside a standard pthread.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-05-24 14:50:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs/commit/75cab832e352ff1cc3ebb8b4c10cf325528ae192', 'message': "[WIP] allow customers to use python standard threads on rabbitmq driver

Propose changes to introduce 2 executions mode for the oslo.messaging
rabbitmq driver:
- mode where eventlet is in use during execution
- mode where python standards thread is in use during execution

The default mode is to use eventlet to don't break existing usages.

Users can switch mode at start by using some additional configuration:
```
[oslo_messaging_rabbit]
eventlet_mode=off
```

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-05-29 11:49:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs/commit/c17e1fe4d7e8352a732b927754167f9171cda82c', 'message': "[WIP] Run heartbeat in a standard pthread by default.

Propose changes to introduce 2 executions mode for the oslo.messaging
rabbitmq driver:
- synchronous execution model based on pthreads [default]
- asynchronous execution model that user can choose to use if needed.

The default mode is to use the python stdlib threading module to run
heartbeat. In mostly use case the user do not take care about the async
mode for the AMQP heartbeat.

The proposed changes will fix related issues who run heartbeat under
mod_wsgi in a monkey patched environment.

If it's really needed users can choose to switch to an async exuction
model by using:
```
[oslo_messaging_rabbit]
async_heartbeat_mode=on
```

In this case the driver will have to check that it's possible to run
async heartbeat (not under mod_wsgi, etc...) and will have to inform
user if the async mode should be forced to off by sending related logs.

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163

commit_message:
Always run the rabbitmq heartbeat inside a standard pthread.

Propose changes to always run the rabbitmq health check heartbeat in a
standard python thread.

With the described specs we want to isolate the heartbeat execution model
from the parent process inherited execution model.

We want to force to use the python stdlib threading module to run
heartbeat.

The proposed changes will fix related issues who run heartbeat under
mod_wsgi in a monkey patched environment.

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/14/661314/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================================================== Allow customer to choose to use std threads or greenthreads in rabbitmq driver ============================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/rabbitmq-driver-threads oslo.messaging RabbitMq driver use greenthreads from eventlet. In some use case it can be useful to also can use python standard threads. This allow customers design that they need exactly in their context. This specification proposes changes to adapt the rabbitmq driver to provide mechanismes needed to lets customers choice between eventlet greenthreads or python standard threads. Problem description =================== The rabbitmq driver is commonly used to healt check the AMQP connections with rabbitmq to ensure connections by using the driver heartbeat mechanism. The AMQP heartbeat can be used in mod_wsgi. the threading library is monkey_patched by eventlet, and it's not compatible with mod_wsgi. Indeed, mod_wsgi stops the execution of its embedded interpreter, the AMQP heartbeat thread can't be resumed until there's a message to be processed in the mod_wsgi queue, which would resume the python interpreter and make eventlet resume the thread. Allow customers to use standard threads and disabling eventlet will fix this kind of issues. Proposed change =============== The spec proposes to introduce a new configuration option who lets customers choose the threading mode to use. By default we'll keep the eventlet mode with the monkey patched threading module, and user by using configuration will can choose to turn off the eventlet mode and to use the non monkey patched mode. The ``eventlet_mode`` config option will be introduced, with the default value defined to turned on (``on``). User can choose to set this value to ``off`` to turn off the eventlet mode and using python standard threads. This option will have a default value so doesn't need to update existing usages. Also the existing usages of this driver will continue to have the same behaviors if nobody changes the configuration explicitely so it's transparent for end users. Here is a example that describes the introduced option turned off:: [oslo_messaging_rabbit] eventlet_mode = off Alternatives ------------ Remove eventlet on the rabbitmq driver and prefer to use possible alternatives like using futurist. Impact on Existing usages ------------------------- No impact on the existing usages since the default behavior will continue to use eventlet by default (``eventlet_mode=on``). Security impact --------------- There's a slim chance that driver behavior could change if pre-existing environment variables are present that happen to match the new option name described here. Performance Impact ------------------ No significant performance impact is expected. Configuration Impact -------------------- A new option will be added that can impact users in some unidentified scenarios. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers will have an additional customization option available. Testing Impact -------------- Additional unit tests will be required to cover the added functionality. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hberaud Other contributors: volunteers? Milestones ---------- ..TODO(hberaud): figure this out Work Items ---------- * Implement the described modes in rabbitmq driver. * Update documentation. * Update the sample configuration generator to include the variable names. * Update the documentation generator to include the variable names. Incubation ========== N/A Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation will need to be updated to indicate the option can be overridden with an environment variable and to describe how the described modes works. Dependencies ============ N/A References ========== * Eventlet Best Practices: `https://review.opendev.org/#/c/154642/`_ * Related discussion on the ML about mod_wsgi and monkey patch: `http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005305.html`_ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Fix docker service masking on Debian and Ubuntu

In the docker role, when running on Debian family hosts, we mask the
docker.service systemd unit before installing docker, to prevent it from
starting unconfigured. We later try to unmask the service using the
Ansible systemd module, however this does not seem to work, and the
service remains masked.

Closes-Bug: #1989704
Change-Id: I74f41381fecbf4b3f263801d43414d334bb6d963
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collection-kolla refs/changes/67/857867/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update CentOS cloud image default username.

The default username for CentOS can be ``cloud-user`` for some latest
stream images because CentOS stream image [1,2] is a continuous-delivery
distribution providing each point-release of RHEL. I have confirmed
locally that the username for CentOS 9 stream is ``cloud-user``. This
update adds an extra possible default username for CentOS image.

Closes-Bug: #1977505

[1]https://wiki.centos.org/Manuals/ReleaseNotes/CentOSStream
[2]https://blog.centos.org/2021/12/introducing-centos-stream-9/

Change-Id: I6cd8448014ebb70eb991cbbeb15a7fb685568689
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/93/846093/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: In a CentOS cloud image, the login account is ``centos``. However, since CentOS Stream is a continuous-delivery distribution providing each point-release of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), the login account for some of the latest stream images can be ``cloud-user``.
deleted_lines: In a CentOS cloud image, the login account is ``centos``.

commit_message:
Skip returning unwanted internal data to user

Various RestFul APIs returns below internal unwanted data to the user:-

trust_id of a lease
resource_id of a reservation
aggregate_id of an instance reservation
trust_id of a host

This patch will not return above data if the microversion is 1.1.

APIImpact:
1)For microversion 1.1, trust_id of a lease, resource_id of a
reservation, aggregate_id of an instance reservation are not returned
in response while creating, updating and getting the lease.

2)For microversion 1.1, trust_id of a host is not returned in
response while creating, updating and getting the host.

Change-Id: Ie6205af3052c972cdb6fb8a9f00afa5c2c8d72a7
Closes-Bug: #1740091

commit_message:
[WIP] Improve linting

Change-Id: Iaa6149ed91ed8d6ad352ff45e21f3c6305b22dcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/13/734913/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:linters] # Env vars and deps need to be defined in top level tox env setenv = ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {toxinidir}/ansible/library ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {toxinidir}/ansible/action_plugins ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {toxinidir}/ansible/filter_plugins deps = -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/master} -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt whitelist_externals = bash commands = ; {[testenv:pep8]commands} {[testenv:doc8]commands} ; {[testenv:bandit]commands} ; {[testenv:bashate]commands} ; {[testenv:yamllint]commands} [testenv:doc8] deps = {[testenv:linters]deps} commands = doc8 doc/source specs doc8 -e '.yaml' releasenotes/notes/

commit_message:
[WIP] [CI] Use kolla-toolbox clients

Change-Id: Ieb54606812d269ad2447c898923ea243486aa9ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/47/843747/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: alias curl='sudo docker exec kolla_toolbox curl' alias openstack='sudo docker exec --env-file /etc/kolla/admin-openrc.sh kolla_toolbox openstack' KOLLA_DEBUG=1 source tools/init-runonce |& gawk '{ print strftime("%F %T"), $0; }' &> /tmp/logs/ansible/init-runonce

commit_message:
Refactor services' check-containers and optimise

This might fix some hidden bugs where the check tasks forgot to
include params important for the service.

We also get a nice optimisation by using a filtered loop instead
of task skipping per service with 'when'.

This refactoring allows for further optimisation and
fixing work to proceed with much less hassle.

One downside is we remove the little optimisation for Zun that
ignored config change for copying loopback but this is an
acceptable tradeoff considering the benefits above.

Change-Id: I855dfef33aa0f3fd1301295bb8ede3e587e7162a
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/43/773243/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - import_role: name: service-check-containers
deleted_lines: - name: Check rally containers become: true kolla_docker: action: "compare_container" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" name: "{{ item.value.container_name }}" image: "{{ item.value.image }}" volumes: "{{ item.value.volumes }}" dimensions: "{{ item.value.dimensions }}" when: - inventory_hostname in groups[item.value.group] - item.value.enabled | bool with_dict: "{{ rally_services }}" notify: - "Restart {{ item.key }} container"

subject: Optimise config
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-08-06 14:51:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/166ec7c7815b4596d55ae5bd8f3dd6edeceb77e5', 'message': "[WIP] Use checks for config and optimize

The proposed approach allows for checking whether config
files are current, e.g. cases when the deployment was aborted after
config files were generated but before they were injected into the
containers which lead to old config staying in containers.

After this patch we can do:
  kolla-ansible genconfig
  kolla-ansible deploy-containers
and it would generally do what we expected rather than being a noop
in the second part.

We also get nice refactoring and lose the need to have notifies
and whens in config and handler sections respectively.
This might fix some hidden bugs where the check tasks forgot to
include params important for the service.

We also get a nice optimization by using filtered loop instead of
task skipping per service with 'when'.

Note this patch builds upon genconfig optimization and it takes it
further by not having genconfig ever touch the handlers!

Oh, and this gets us closer to the single responsibility principle -
config only generates the config, container checks only validate
whether container restart is needed.

Future work:
- optimize for large files
  - could we get away with comparing timestamps and sizes?
    container's should have a newer timestamp due to copy,
    could also preserve it
- optimize config by doing local generation and mass rsync
- support for reloads
- unconditional restart/reload (separate action)
- make 'reconfigure' act like 'genconfig' + 'deploy-containers'
  - this would avoid calling bootstrapping each time but might
    be tricky as it would break current compatibility
  - could call this 'reconfigure-containers' and deprecate
    'reconfigure'

WIP: PoC for Neutron to let you validate the approach.

Change-Id: I0ce24043ae5486b2b55489ba40abe2b96b0991a6
Closes-Bug: the-one-with-config-in-place
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/745105
Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-08-12 18:53:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/fd62cbc989d50c89821be88398fa1953cfa5772a', 'message': "[WIP] Use checks for config and optimize

commit_message:
Optimise config

This patch builds upon genconfig optimisation and it takes it
further by not having genconfig ever touch the handlers!
It also depends on the config checking fix.

I have noticed some handlers missing the necessary guard,
making genconfig actually able to restart some containers before.
This patches fixes that.

Oh, and this gets us closer to the single responsibility principle -
config only generates the config, container checks only validate
whether container restart is needed.

Future work:
- optimise config by doing local generation and mass rsync
- support for reloads
- unconditional restart/reload (separate action)
- make 'reconfigure' act like 'genconfig' + 'deploy-containers'
  - this would avoid calling bootstrapping each time but might
    be tricky as it would break current compatibility
  - could call this 'reconfigure-containers' and deprecate
    'reconfigure'

Change-Id: I0ce24043ae5486b2b55489ba40abe2b96b0991a6
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/773246

deleted_lines: - name: Check neutron containers become: true kolla_docker: action: "compare_container" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" name: "{{ item.value.container_name }}" image: "{{ item.value.image }}" privileged: "{{ item.value.privileged | default(False) }}" volumes: "{{ item.value.volumes }}" dimensions: "{{ item.value.dimensions }}" when: - item.value.enabled | bool - item.value.host_in_groups | bool with_dict: "{{ neutron_services }}" notify: - "Restart {{ item.key }} container"

commit_message:
Glance Cinder backend

Implement proper support for the Glance's Cinder backend on demand
instead of enabling a broken support by default.

There were several bits missing from the original logic that kept
the Cinder backend kind of available but broken in multiple ways.
For details, please see the bug reports and the attached release
note.

Docs included as well.

Closes-Bug: #1928669
Closes-Bug: #1831002
Related-Bug: #1854194
Change-Id: Ia5198e4f2c12290546be7204e94d6bc72c7868a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/99/714999/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance_backend_cinder: "yes"

commit_message:
[CI] Change the Zun scenario to altcomp scenario

As discussed some time ago, we prefer to have the alternative
compute (altcomp) scenario which covers other ways to deploy
the compute plane.
The scenario keeps Zun but the new name reinforces the fact
that this scenario is testing more than Zun.

At the moment, the scenario runs multinode compute with Cinder
LVM-backed volumes. This is our only scenario to test non-Ceph
Cinder (which is best to validate if only Ceph is affected).
In the future, this may (and likely will) include the deployment
of additional services, like Blazar, similarly to how Zun is
included currently.

Change-Id: I2651be1b5073b3395e47e8d0de1b540cb6d17457

subject: Get OVS assignment right
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-05-06 13:11:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/72e528394d1e5031d0bb61829b81014d59a5dcfd', 'message': 'Get OVS assignment right

As reported in the linked bug, the OVS role has issues with actual
placement. This patch gets it right. It avoids the use of static
inventory entirely and is backwards compatible. Only correct hosts

commit_message:
Get OVS assignment right

As reported in the linked bug, the OVS role has issues with actual
placement. This patch gets it right. It avoids the use of static
inventory entirely and is backwards compatible. Only correct hosts
will now have the OVS logic applied.

Closes-Bug: #1971488
Change-Id: Ie92b6a27a656491601606b76e410e247f82b46b1

commit_message:
Add the NATS transport driver to oslo.messaging

nats-transport is the spec for a new transport driver for
oslo.messaging to use the NATS messaging system.

Change-Id: Ic6346947bbf650fb53581842c64fdec99090c242
Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/nats-transport
Co-Authored-By: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/84/692784/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =====================================:wq NATS Driver for Messaging Transport ===================================== This specification proposes a new transport driver for oslo.messaging that uses NATS. NATS is a high-performance messaging system [1]_ [2]_ written in Go. NATS is designed as a central nervous system for the cloud control plane [3]_. While NATS Sreaming has message persistency like RabbitMQ, NATS itself doesn't but it's not a problem for oslo.messaging because every message has its own lifetime. NATS server supports clustering for high availability. Problem description =================== RabbitMQ is widely used in OpenStack deployments but it has problems: * Big footprint: RabbitMQ is only one using Erlang for a typical OpenStack deployment and it requires 40MB+ disk space and ~30 packages in Ubuntu. RDO stein contains 43 packages of Erlang. * HA performance: "Avoid multiple nodes (HA)" is one of the best practices from the point of view of performance [4]_. * HA stability: Japanese OpenStackers discussed RabbitMQ operation problems at OpenStack Ops Workshop #6 at Tokyo [5]_ and an attendee said that clustered RabbitMQ servers in his OpenStack deployment suddenly died without failover and he decided to stop using RabbitMQ clustering. Proposed change =============== Implements a new driver of oslo.messaging to use NATS as the RPC and notification message transport. It uses pynats2 [6]_, threading based python 3.6+ client for NATS. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- Nothing. Security impact --------------- Nothing. The NATS driver should have 2 security capabilities like other drivers: authentication and encryption. pynats2 python client library has both, so we can use them in the driver. Performance Impact ------------------ Nothing. Configuration Impact -------------------- To use the NATS driver, spefify the value for transport_url in section [Default]: transport_url = nats://[user:pass@]host[:port][,[userN:passN@]hostN:portN]/[virtual_host] For TLS connection, transport_url = nats+tls://[user:pass@]host[:port][,[userN:passN@]hostN:portN]/[virtual_host] The default value of port is 4222. You can specify multiple hosts with each user:pass. The NATS server doesn't support virtual host but pynats2 module has pseudo virtual host capability and the driver uses it. The driver has options in section [oslo_messaging_nats]: socket_timeout: Seconds to waiting recieved data from NATS server Type: float Default value: 2.0 ping_interval: Interval in seconds to send PING to NATS server Type: float Default value: 10.0 tls_verify: Verify the NATS server certificate Type: bool Default value: False tls_cacert: path to the CA certificate file for the NATS server verification Type: string tls_client_cert: path to the client certificate file for the NATS connection Type: string tls_client_key: path to the client key file for the NATS connection Type: string Developer Impact ---------------- Nothing. Testing Impact -------------- The NATS server will be used as the messaging backend for RPC and notifications in testing. No alternative backend such as RabbitMQ or Apache Kafka should be used. The NATS driver tests should be implemented and the driver must pass all tests. The driver must pass the following gate checks with deployed in a hybrid messaging configuration. * oslo.messaging-tox-py36-func-nats pynats2 python client library only supports Python 3.6+. It doesn't use asyncio, so we can make it available with Python 2.x. However, Python 2.x will be unsupported on Jan 1st, 2020, and the NATS driver won't be required backward compatibility because it's new one, so gates for Python 2.x won't be used or implemented for it. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: akirayoshiyama@gmail.com (Akira72 or yosshy on IRC) Other contributors: No one for now. Contributors are welcome. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: V release Work Items ---------- * Deploy environment for latest software release and dependencies * Implement the NATS driver * Write documentation * Functional test integration * Implement devstack plugin * Upstream CI integration * Send announcement to openstack-discuss following release Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- The NATS driver is expected to be adopted in many deployments which operators doesn't like to use RabbitMQ. Library ------- oslo.messaging Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None Documentation Impact ==================== The NATS driver documentation will be added to the libary. This documentation will follow the style of documentation provided by the other drivers and should include the following topics: * theory of operation (overview) of the NATS messaging backend * pre-requisites * driver options overview * the NATS server operations * devstack support * platforms and software Dependencies ============ The driver will require pynats2, threading based NATS python client. References ========== .. [1] https://nats.io/ .. [2] https://bravenewgeek.com/dissecting-message-queues/ .. [3] https://nats.io/blog/introducing-nats-streaming/#why-nats-streaming .. [4] https://www.cloudamqp.com/blog/2018-01-08-part2-rabbitmq-best-practice-for-high-performance.html#avoid-multiple-nodes-ha .. [5] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/JP-Ops-workshop-6-rabbit .. [6] https://github.com/yosshy/pynats2 .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Test created encrypted volume type

Created encrypted volume type is not tested properly
to know if that is created successfully or usable or not.

This commit adds the created encrypted volume type in bootale
volume creation request which is used to boot instance from.

Related-Bug: #1926630
Related-Bug: #1938763
Change-Id: Id16f5b57e88a1efe52a51a83656d770d190695aa

commit_message:
Project Stopwatch

This is a proposal to change our release cycles, simplifying
our procedures.

Change-Id: I1875855e8accfbb7ff64af1781f0856c12760c11
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ideas refs/changes/29/718929/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Project Stopwatch: Changing the release cycle ============================================= Despite talking regularly about changing release cycles, we keep the same process, and our releases cycles stay about 6 months long. There are multiple issues we should look at: pressure on our contributors, large delays (around 6 months) if you miss the feature freeze, inflexible release models, lack of contributions/releases in stable branches for some projects. The pressure on our contributors comes from multiple aspects. On top of being shorthanded, we have many release cycle deadlines, including a very stressful feature freeze for which many developers can't wait the next release to have their feature included and must apply pressure to get their work merged in time. Having a longer release cycles wouldn't help our people as there would be even more pressure on our current deadlines (like library and feature freezes). However, after the feature freeze, more time could be spent for project maintenance and janitoring. Would shorter cycles solve those main issues? Not really. What we gain in agility (it would help to not wait for 6 months when missing a release deadline), would directly translate into the pressure on individuals. At first sight, the same amount of work would need to be done in less time. It is worth noting that increasing the amount of feature freezes would reduce the pressure at each feature freeze. My proposal to solve those issues is to remap and automate what's happening inside a cycle, increase the amount of feature freezes, and relax the requirements of what needs to happen in a cycle. Its advantages are: less pressure on individuals, increased stability, reduced load on maintainers, and decrease the importance of "coordinated" releasing. Its main inconvenient would be to have more "freeze" time, slowering the pace (though this could be considered an advantage), and reduce the attractiveness on occasional maintainers (this has to be balanced with the healthy improvements of a reduced pace for the rest of the community). The stopwatch (tick-tock) model for coordinated release -------------------------------------------------------- For the "coordinated" releases, we would take a "tick-tock" approach, where one month the features are introduced ('tick', on odd months), and on the next month ('tock'), we'll stabilise. It introduces: * a specific focus each month * more feature freezes (every odd month) * more time for bug fixing (every other month), helping on stability * a standard rhythm for the community * more opportunities to ramp up the community members It removes: * the complexity of the current schedule * the need for release candidates * a bit of the speed of the current developments Please note that new developments do not have to stop or be abandonned in the "stabilisation" month. They are just not merged until we are sure the rest of the code is stabilized. Long term contributors will have more time to focus on project janitorial work. I also hope this extra time of stabilization could be spent on growing the community, and more mentoring. However, a negative side-effect would be that some features contributions could take longer to merge, as the features only happen on "tick" months. This side-effect should be carefully examinated before a policy like this can be set in place. The rhythm proposed could be used to automate release proposals. To kickstart this, we could convert all the "cycle-with-rc", "cycle-with-intermediary", and "cycle-automatic" projects into a single release model, behaving like "c-w-i". It has the positive side-effect to simplify the work for the project's release liaisons, and for the releases team too. Note: The deliverable types don't need to change, as they mark explicitly what kind of software is delivered. In terms of tagging and releasing, the developers are still encouraged to push features up early, by having them tagged, even if they are not fully polished, on odd months. The difference with "the old way", is that those early features won't be named as "milestones" anymore. They are simple, regular, releases -- their content being recognizable using semver. Release liaisons can continue to iterate during the cycle until the official coordinated release lands, where the official cycle-highlights and release notes will be officially made public by default. Of course, bug fixes can be tagged and pushed at all times, and are now more encouraged than ever. Now we can discuss how will it impact releasing, branching, stabilisation, freezes, cycle highlights. An automatic stopwatch ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ At the middle of each calendar month (whether it's a tick or a tock month), a release will be automatically proposed, and reviewed by the project's releases liaison(s), and by the release team. The work of the releases' liaison is to ensure the commit SHA of the release is significant: the last SHA introducing a feature for odd ("tick", "feature") months before the stabilization period, or the last commit SHA before a new feature lands in the even ("tock", "stabilization") months. The work of the release team is to ensure that the rules are followed, for a consistent behaviour across OpenStack projects, and reject release proposals that don't match the expected. By having some kind of rhythm, and the automation around releasing, we'll reduce the stress of the countdowns. All the odds months will look the same, all the even months will look the same. No exceptions in the way. A cycle stays simple and behaves like clockwork. A project should be allowed to not propose any release if nothing is worth releasing. Projects having nothing to release for the first 4 months will be moved to "independent" on the next cycle, see below. Branching during the cycle ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ We'll continue branching as usual. The coordinated release happens every 6 months currently. In this case, we should branch at 4th month of a cycle, an even (stabilization) month. This makes the newly cut branch already very stable (like we have now), except that it's not because it just went through multiple RCs, but simply because it already has experienced 2 effective months of stabilisation. We used to avoid introducing features at the end of the cycle. This can stay. Developers can start to work on next release starting with month 5. Handle existing stable branches ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ With every other month being used for stabilisation, I would expect more time could be spent on on backporting the bug fixes more actively into stable branches. With more efforts into stable branches, it might become interesting to automatically propose stable branches releases every "tock" months. This would improve on the current situation where some projects don't release their stable branches frequently. Removal of the spec and feature freezes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There is no reason to keep the spec and feature freezes, as they were used to prevent large features to get introduced too late in the cycle. Worst case scenario, a large feature gets implemented at the end of the third month. It gives a whole whopping 3 months to get the problem fixed, 1 month without the need of backporting. Cycle highlights ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ They can be written when the release is proposed on the odd months. They will be regularily built by distilling what were the big changes of the month. It's easy to inspect with the release tooling too. We could even improve the new-release tool to help propose them. (Client) library freezes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Libraries can follow the same 'tick-tock' model. To consume new features of libraries, a project can simply "bump the libraries" versions at the beggining of a feature month, which will consume the last 2-months effort of a library. We could think of automating this. As projects are allowed to tag more frequently than once a month, a library usage could even be "fast tracked" into a service: The PoC change in the library can get released early, and the consumption of it can be directly introduced in the project during the same month. As bumps during 'tock' months would be allowed for bug fixing, it would allow a very fast iterative model. In this model, we would recommend to tag libraries more frequently than every month. With all of this in mind, there is no need to do a 'client library freeze', as the freeze effectively happens by having the 'tock' months. Even if a new feature is introduced in a library during "month 3", we'll have have enough time to consume it in projects and/or fix any eventual major bugs by release time. As a picture is worth more than a thousand words, compare `Ussuri release schedule table <https://releases.openstack.org/ussuri/schedule.html>`_ with the table below. I added in this table the feature/stability work, for emphasis. For a fair comparison between the tables, they should be removed. A cycle is still pretty busy, but the work seems more spread around: +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Month number | OpenStack-wide Events | Project-specific Events | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 1 | * Feature work | | | | * Removal of deprecations | | | | * Bump external libraries | | | | * Automatic major tag | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 2 | * Stability work | | | | * Automatic patch tag | | | | * Current cycle goals | | | | implementation starting | | | | (to be merged month 3) | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 3 | * Feature work | * Manila Driver deadlines | | | * Automatic minor tag | * Cinder Driver deadlines | | | * Membership freeze? | | | | * Community goals implemented | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 4 | * Stability work | * Extra-ATC deadline | | | * Automatic patch tag | * PTL elections | | | * Branching with patch tag | * Cinder 3rd party CI | | | * TC elections | compliance checkpoint | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 5 | * Cycle highlights | * Next series goals | | | * Stability work | research and PoC | | | * Automatic patch tag | | | | * Feature work (next branch) | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 6 | * Stability work | | | | * Manual patch tag: | | | | Final release | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ Simpler releases for other models --------------------------------- The projects who don't want to follow the 'tick-tock' model (due to its rigidity) would be moved to an "independent" release model. The only difference between the "independent" and the "tick-tock" model is the strictness of the release coordination, for projects which don't need it. This effectively removes the "cycle-trailing" and "tagless" release models. It brings: * Simplified procedures for the release teams (only 2 models remain) * Simplified/uniform tooling that the release team maintains (remove the conditions and special cases) * An improved quality of life, flexibility, and power to "independent" projects. Release would need to make possible for "independent" projects to use the same tooling as the tick-tock coordinated releases. In other words, the release team will need to extend the tooling to allow branching, tagging, and publication of independent (but official OpenStack) projects on PyPI. After all, they are all OpenStack projects, so they should benefit from the ecosystem tools made by the release team. "Independent" projects won't be required to tag during the cycle. Difference between official and unofficial projects --------------------------------------------------- The difference between an official project and an unofficial project would then be the support of the foundation, and the support of the community. The consumers can be ensured that the official projects behave the same way, follow the same goals, and have the same requirements (like PTI, tested distributions, etc.). In other words, ensured about the cohesion. Official projects would also benefit from the marketing power of the foundation. Removal of this policy ---------------------- Assuming OpenStack arrives at a stability focus point, we will be able to easily observe that not many features are shipped during the feature months. This will allow us to remove this policy, while keeping the automation in place. It will then increase the flexibility further, by effectively removing the "tick-tock", and only the "independent" model would remain.

commit_message:
Add octavia-amphora-image-build-live jobs

From time to time DIB changes break Octavia amphora images. Amphora
images also build upon different configurations than the ones in DIB CI
so they would provide additional test coverage to the project.

These two new jobs are primarily meant to help flag regressions
impacting but not limited to Octavia Ubuntu and CentOS amphora images.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745820/
Change-Id: I0b6b4afb44c15d4ee14d5c3381a3c6edc034a5f7

commit_message:
osc-check-plugins job: Ensure OSC plugins from git

openstackclient-check-plugins did not install OSC plugins
from git even when they are specified in required-projects.
This happened "item.short_name" is not evaluated.

Change-Id: I069e63005ad2cd24f134fee475fa246bf324a7e2

commit_message:
Configure ceph for glance if multiple stores is enabled

Glance has support to configure multiple stores from Stein release. Recently
support for configuring multiple filesystem stores for glance is added. In
this patch we are configuring ceph if both multiple stores is enabled
using 'GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True' and ceph is also
enabled.

In order to configure ceph with support to multiple stores using devstack
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True
enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph
ENABLE_CEPH_GLANCE=True

NOTE: These changes are required as soon glance is set to remove single
store support in Victoria cycle.

Change-Id: I210e711aab742e005badc919ec040febb9f45f7f

commit_message:
[WIP] Getting Started documentation

This patch adds the "Getting Started" section of the JavaScript API's
documentation. Given a cloud and provided credentials, this guide
should take a user from authentication to accessing an instance in
no more than 30 minutes. It is also a design document, intended to
demonstrate the desired simplicity of the SDK.

Method names have been inspired by the openstack commandline client,
using the format <service>.<resource><Action>().

Change-Id: I05293f3ff733f7978c7df23f4ee0fdf401a495b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/75/351875/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Getting startedIN PROGRESS DRAFT NOTES: * Make a note about browser vs. node apps. * Note isomorphism and language usage. * Include generator-openstack project setup. Who should read this guide ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This guide is for experienced software developers, who want to interact with an OpenStack cloud using the JavaScript SDK. TODO: expand on this? What you will learn ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This guide will teach you how to authenticate against an OpenStack cloud, boot compute instances, and connect them to a network. TODO: expand on this? What you need ------------- We assume that you can already access an OpenStack cloud. You must have a project, also known as a tenant, with a minimum quota of one instance. You will also need a development environment with a recent version of Node.js and npm available, as well as an optional web browser. You will also need to obtain the following information from your cloud provider: * Auth URL (example: http://example.com:35357/) * User name * Password * Project ID or Name (projects are also known as tenants) * Cloud Region Most of these values are available from the Horizon Dashboard. Log in, and click :guilabel:`Project->Access & Security->API Access->Download OpenStack RC file`. If you use this method, be aware that our "Auth URL" does not include the path. For example, if the dashboard :file:`openrc.sh` file shows: .. code-block:: bash export OS_AUTH_URL=http://controller:5000/v2.0 The actual auth URL is: `http://controller:5000` Setting up your project ----------------------- TODO: Basic instructions on how to use generator-openstack to create a bare openstack test environment. The instructions should either explicitly create a clouds.yaml file, or a user should be prompted for input parameters, so that generator-openstack will build it for her. TODO: Side note that impatient developers can choose one of the pre-existing browser or nodejs projects instead. TODO: Describe the important portions of the generated test environment. This MUST include the clouds.yaml file. Maybe the clouds.yaml file that's generated can include documentation? Step 1: Authenticate to your cloud ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Brief intro stating that one must first authenticate against the clouds's API (keystone). TODO: Link the below sample code to an actual sample script in js-openstack-lib's test directory (this should be gate tested). .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Identity; // Include code to load YAML file? const identity = new Identity(config); identity .authenticate() .then(identity.listCatalog) .then((catalog) => { console.log("Authentication Successful"); console.log("Service Catalog:", catalog); }); Step 2: Retrieve a list of Compute Flavors ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Text.... .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Compute; // Note identity in the constructor. const compute = new Compute(identity); compute.listFlavors() // Is this a good name? How should these be formatted? .then((flavors) => { console.log(flavors); }); Step 3: Retrieve a list of Disk Images ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Text.... .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Images; // Note identity in the constructor. const images = new Identity(identity); images.listImages() // Is this a good name? How should these be formatted? .then((images) => { console.log(images); }); Step 4: Upload a Key Pair ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Text.... .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Compute; const compute = new Compute(identity); compute .keypairAdd( /* params... ? */ ) .then(compute.keypairList) .then((keypairs) => { console.log(keypairs); }); Step 5: Boot a server ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Text.... .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Compute; const compute = new Compute(identity); compute .serverCreate(name, image, flavor, key) .then((server) => { console.log(server); }); Step 6: Create and attach a network. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO: Different clouds handle default networking differently. Try to see what the firstapp guide does and import that text? .. code-block:: javascript from openstack-lib import Network; const networkService = new Network(identity); network .networkCreate( /* params? */) .then((net) => { return network.attach(net, server); }) .then(() => { console.log("Server attached to network!"); });

commit_message:
Replace deprecated assertDictContainsSubset

The method is deprecated since Python 3.2[1] and shows the following
DeprecationWarning.

/usr/lib/python3.9/unittest/case.py:1134: DeprecationWarning:
assertDictContainsSubset is deprecated
  warnings.warn('assertDictContainsSubset is deprecated',

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.2.html#unittest

Closes-Bug: #1987013
Change-Id: Id97ed5b9aa8176d1b8bd189365cc7978def8ccab
